Tribe Nine Episode 12  by Mercedez Clewis, Mar 30th 2022                   How would you rate episode 12 of Tribe Nine ?                     Community score: 3.7            Time to get ready to play ball, which is coincidentally the title of Tribe Nine's grand slam of a finale (that is, “PLAY BALL” in all caps) to what I can only assume will be a one cour project as, spoiler alert: it has very little baseball, actually. But there's lots and lots of feelings.    Ojiro goes full mask off (as in, he literally takes off his mask) this week, taking on the Minato Tribe in a face-to-face battle that's full of twists and turns, including a good bit of betrayal. I love a last-minute heel turn (with GUNS!), even if it's crammed into twenty-four minutes of not the best paced scripting. But hey: that banger soundtrack though, am I right?    There is so much crammed into this episode: there's flashbacks and XB fights (and even more almost XB fights) and character growth and character deconstruction. It's all a lot, and it's not necessarily well-structured. It is fairly interesting, but maybe, in another series it would be well-executed and not feel like Tribe Nine was trying to tie up a bunch of loose ends. It ultimately feels messy, and when the resolution comes it's expected, which is really all I can say.    And since we're here, let's talk about resolutions.    I can easily say I'll be leaving the series with a solid sense of closure and a bit of optimism, which is nice, but unexpected. I genuinely thought I'd be leaving with some sort of “now go play the mobile game” bait, but instead we get an ending that feels about as good as you can expect from a show that's gone through some very high highs and extremely low lows like Tribe Nine has, cliffhangers included.    And goodness me, has this show gone through it over the past few weeks.    But where the show lands -and actually sticks the landing- is on the notion of fun. Part of why XB is so engaging for the late Shun Kamiya, and now, for Haru, is because it's a game. XB thrives when that's at the core: when it becomes a knock down, drag out battle, the game loses it's enjoyment. And it's actually this return to fun by Haru -who literally throws hands this episode- that actually kind of had me smiling in the end because say what you will, this show stays the course with its overall message, roiling the world of XB and Neo Tokyo by Game Over-ing some characters. (Or are they alive? Here's the thing, I genuinely don't know.)    Tribe Nine is a series that I don't regret spending time with, if only because of my insatiable desire to devour everything Kazutaka Kodaka lays his hands on. I just kind of can't help myself: every since I played Danganronpa in grad school, I've been very into everything he makes. Tribe Nine is the fast food of anime. It is is the 7-11 pizza slice of the animation world. Will it do in a pinch? Yeah, of course, but is it exactly what I wanted?    No, not at all.    There was a lot of mixed feelings as the credits rolled: I tried to reflect on what drew me to this show outside of my desire to kin my personality into every single Danganronpa character. Thinking back, it was a desire to see  a sports anime that was fun, and to a degree Tribe Nine was, at least initially. That said, I know there was an audience for this series, and I really hope that if you're that audience, you enjoyed it. Truth be told, that's always my wish for shows that I'm reviewing, whether or not I like them in the end: I hope that they brought enjoyment to as many people as possible. I'm a bit on both sides of the fence with my enjoyment, but honestly I can safely conclude this review saying that this anime is perfectly okay, and that's okay in and of itself. Every season needs its C-minus grade anime, and Tribe Nine?    Well, it's a grand slam in that category.    Rating:              because this was so close to four stars, but just never got there       Tribe Nine is currently streaming on Funimation.    Mercedez is a JP-EN translation and localization light novel editor & proofreader/QA, pop culture critic, and a journalist who, when not writing for ANN, writes for Anime Feminist, where they're a staff editor. They're also a frequent cohost on the Anime Feminist Podcast, Chatty AF. This season, they're reflecting on their youth with Akebi's Sailor Uniform. Tribe Nine Episode 12  by Mercedez Clewis, Mar 30th 2022                   How would you rate episode 12 of Tribe Nine ?                     Community score: 3.7            Time to get ready to play ball, which is coincidentally the title of Tribe Nine's grand slam of a finale (that is, “PLAY BALL” in all caps) to what I can only assume will be a one cour project as, spoiler alert: it has very little baseball, actually. But there's lots and lots of feelings.    Ojiro goes full mask off (as in, he literally takes off his mask) this week, taking on the Minato Tribe in a face-to-face battle that's full of twists and turns, including a good bit of betrayal. I love a last-minute heel turn (with GUNS!), even if it's crammed into twenty-four minutes of not the best paced scripting. But hey: that banger soundtrack though, am I right?    There is so much crammed into this episode: there's flashbacks and XB fights (and even more almost XB fights) and character growth and character deconstruction. It's all a lot, and it's not necessarily well-structured. It is fairly interesting, but maybe, in another series it would be well-executed and not feel like Tribe Nine was trying to tie up a bunch of loose ends. It ultimately feels messy, and when the resolution comes it's expected, which is really all I can say.    And since we're here, let's talk about resolutions.    I can easily say I'll be leaving the series with a solid sense of closure and a bit of optimism, which is nice, but unexpected. I genuinely thought I'd be leaving with some sort of “now go play the mobile game” bait, but instead we get an ending that feels about as good as you can expect from a show that's gone through some very high highs and extremely low lows like Tribe Nine has, cliffhangers included.    And goodness me, has this show gone through it over the past few weeks.    But where the show lands -and actually sticks the landing- is on the notion of fun. Part of why XB is so engaging for the late Shun Kamiya, and now, for Haru, is because it's a game. XB thrives when that's at the core: when it becomes a knock down, drag out battle, the game loses it's enjoyment. And it's actually this return to fun by Haru -who literally throws hands this episode- that actually kind of had me smiling in the end because say what you will, this show stays the course with its overall message, roiling the world of XB and Neo Tokyo by Game Over-ing some characters. (Or are they alive? Here's the thing, I genuinely don't know.)    Tribe Nine is a series that I don't regret spending time with, if only because of my insatiable desire to devour everything Kazutaka Kodaka lays his hands on. I just kind of can't help myself: every since I played Danganronpa in grad school, I've been very into everything he makes. Tribe Nine is the fast food of anime. It is is the 7-11 pizza slice of the animation world. Will it do in a pinch? Yeah, of course, but is it exactly what I wanted?    No, not at all.    There was a lot of mixed feelings as the credits rolled: I tried to reflect on what drew me to this show outside of my desire to kin my personality into every single Danganronpa character. Thinking back, it was a desire to see  a sports anime that was fun, and to a degree Tribe Nine was, at least initially. That said, I know there was an audience for this series, and I really hope that if you're that audience, you enjoyed it. Truth be told, that's always my wish for shows that I'm reviewing, whether or not I like them in the end: I hope that they brought enjoyment to as many people as possible. I'm a bit on both sides of the fence with my enjoyment, but honestly I can safely conclude this review saying that this anime is perfectly okay, and that's okay in and of itself. Every season needs its C-minus grade anime, and Tribe Nine?    Well, it's a grand slam in that category. Tribe Nine Episode 12  by Mercedez Clewis, Mar 30th 2022                   How would you rate episode 12 of Tribe Nine ?                     Community score: 3.7            Time to get ready to play ball, which is coincidentally the title of Tribe Nine's grand slam of a finale (that is, “PLAY BALL” in all caps) to what I can only assume will be a one cour project as, spoiler alert: it has very little baseball, actually. But there's lots and lots of feelings.    Ojiro goes full mask off (as in, he literally takes off his mask) this week, taking on the Minato Tribe in a face-to-face battle that's full of twists and turns, including a good bit of betrayal. I love a last-minute heel turn (with GUNS!), even if it's crammed into twenty-four minutes of not the best paced scripting. But hey: that banger soundtrack though, am I right?    There is so much crammed into this episode: there's flashbacks and XB fights (and even more almost XB fights) and character growth and character deconstruction. It's all a lot, and it's not necessarily well-structured. It is fairly interesting, but maybe, in another series it would be well-executed and not feel like Tribe Nine was trying to tie up a bunch of loose ends. It ultimately feels messy, and when the resolution comes it's expected, which is really all I can say.    And since we're here, let's talk about resolutions.    I can easily say I'll be leaving the series with a solid sense of closure and a bit of optimism, which is nice, but unexpected. I genuinely thought I'd be leaving with some sort of “now go play the mobile game” bait, but instead we get an ending that feels about as good as you can expect from a show that's gone through some very high highs and extremely low lows like Tribe Nine has, cliffhangers included.    And goodness me, has this show gone through it over the past few weeks.    But where the show lands -and actually sticks the landing- is on the notion of fun. Part of why XB is so engaging for the late Shun Kamiya, and now, for Haru, is because it's a game. XB thrives when that's at the core: when it becomes a knock down, drag out battle, the game loses it's enjoyment. And it's actually this return to fun by Haru -who literally throws hands this episode- that actually kind of had me smiling in the end because say what you will, this show stays the course with its overall message, roiling the world of XB and Neo Tokyo by Game Over-ing some characters. (Or are they alive? Here's the thing, I genuinely don't know.)    Tribe Nine is a series that I don't regret spending time with, if only because of my insatiable desire to devour everything Kazutaka Kodaka lays his hands on. I just kind of can't help myself: every since I played Danganronpa in grad school, I've been very into everything he makes. Tribe Nine is the fast food of anime. It is is the 7-11 pizza slice of the animation world. Will it do in a pinch? Yeah, of course, but is it exactly what I wanted?    No, not at all.    There was a lot of mixed feelings as the credits rolled: I tried to reflect on what drew me to this show outside of my desire to kin my personality into every single Danganronpa character. Thinking back, it was a desire to see  a sports anime that was fun, and to a degree Tribe Nine was, at least initially. That said, I know there was an audience for this series, and I really hope that if you're that audience, you enjoyed it. Truth be told, that's always my wish for shows that I'm reviewing, whether or not I like them in the end: I hope that they brought enjoyment to as many people as possible. I'm a bit on both sides of the fence with my enjoyment, but honestly I can safely conclude this review saying that this anime is perfectly okay, and that's okay in and of itself. Every season needs its C-minus grade anime, and Tribe Nine?    Well, it's a grand slam in that category.    Rating:              because this was so close to four stars, but just never got there       Tribe Nine is currently streaming on Funimation.    Mercedez is a JP-EN translation and localization light novel editor & proofreader/QA, pop culture critic, and a journalist who, when not writing for ANN, writes for Anime Feminist, where they're a staff editor. They're also a frequent cohost on the Anime Feminist Podcast, Chatty AF. This season, they're reflecting on their youth with Akebi's Sailor Uniform. Title: Episode 12 - Tribe Nine - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: ×  remind me tomorrow remind me next week never remind me      Subscribe to the ANN Newsletter • Wake up every Sunday to a curated list of ANN's most interesting posts of the week.    read more           ข่าวสารและบทความของ Anime News Network ในรูปแบบภาษาไทย สามารถติดตามอ่านได้แล้วที่ DEXclub         กรุณาเข้าไปเยี่ยมชมได้ที่ news.dexclub.com เพื่อติดตามอ่านข่าวสารล่าสุดในรูปแบบภาษาไทย          Anime News Network's news and articles are available in Thai from DEXclub.         Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.                Tribe Nine Episode 12  by Mercedez Clewis, Mar 30th 2022                   How would you rate episode 12 of Tribe Nine ?                     Community score: 3.7            Time to get ready to play ball, which is coincidentally the title of Tribe Nine's grand slam of a finale (that is, “PLAY BALL” in all caps) to what I can only assume will be a one cour project as, spoiler alert: it has very little baseball, actually. But there's lots and lots of feelings.    Ojiro goes full mask off (as in, he literally takes off his mask) this week, taking on the Minato Tribe in a face-to-face battle that's full of twists and turns, including a good bit of betrayal. I love a last-minute heel turn (with GUNS!), even if it's crammed into twenty-four minutes of not the best paced scripting. But hey: that banger soundtrack though, am I right?    There is so much crammed into this episode: there's flashbacks and XB fights (and even more almost XB fights) and character growth and character deconstruction. It's all a lot, and it's not necessarily well-structured. It is fairly interesting, but maybe, in another series it would be well-executed and not feel like Tribe Nine was trying to tie up a bunch of loose ends. It ultimately feels messy, and when the resolution comes it's expected, which is really all I can say.    And since we're here, let's talk about resolutions.    I can easily say I'll be leaving the series with a solid sense of closure and a bit of optimism, which is nice, but unexpected. I genuinely thought I'd be leaving with some sort of “now go play the mobile game” bait, but instead we get an ending that feels about as good as you can expect from a show that's gone through some very high highs and extremely low lows like Tribe Nine has, cliffhangers included.    And goodness me, has this show gone through it over the past few weeks.    But where the show lands -and actually sticks the landing- is on the notion of fun. Part of why XB is so engaging for the late Shun Kamiya, and now, for Haru, is because it's a game. XB thrives when that's at the core: when it becomes a knock down, drag out battle, the game loses it's enjoyment. And it's actually this return to fun by Haru -who literally throws hands this episode- that actually kind of had me smiling in the end because say what you will, this show stays the course with its overall message, roiling the world of XB and Neo Tokyo by Game Over-ing some characters. (Or are they alive? Here's the thing, I genuinely don't know.)    Tribe Nine is a series that I don't regret spending time with, if only because of my insatiable desire to devour everything Kazutaka Kodaka lays his hands on. I just kind of can't help myself: every since I played Danganronpa in grad school, I've been very into everything he makes. Tribe Nine is the fast food of anime. It is is the 7-11 pizza slice of the animation world. Will it do in a pinch? Yeah, of course, but is it exactly what I wanted?    No, not at all.    There was a lot of mixed feelings as the credits rolled: I tried to reflect on what drew me to this show outside of my desire to kin my personality into every single Danganronpa character. Thinking back, it was a desire to see  a sports anime that was fun, and to a degree Tribe Nine was, at least initially. That said, I know there was an audience for this series, and I really hope that if you're that audience, you enjoyed it. Truth be told, that's always my wish for shows that I'm reviewing, whether or not I like them in the end: I hope that they brought enjoyment to as many people as possible. I'm a bit on both sides of the fence with my enjoyment, but honestly I can safely conclude this review saying that this anime is perfectly okay, and that's okay in and of itself. Every season needs its C-minus grade anime, and Tribe Nine?    Well, it's a grand slam in that category.    Rating:              because this was so close to four stars, but just never got there       Tribe Nine is currently streaming on Funimation.    Mercedez is a JP-EN translation and localization light novel editor & proofreader/QA, pop culture critic, and a journalist who, when not writing for ANN, writes for Anime Feminist, where they're a staff editor. They're also a frequent cohost on the Anime Feminist Podcast, Chatty AF. This season, they're reflecting on their youth with Akebi's Sailor Uniform. XB thrives when that's at the core: when it becomes a knock down, drag out battle, the game loses it's enjoyment. And it's actually this return to fun by Haru -who literally throws hands this episode- that actually kind of had me smiling in the end because say what you will, this show stays the course with its overall message, roiling the world of XB and Neo Tokyo by Game Over-ing some characters. (Or are they alive? Here's the thing, I genuinely don't know.)    Tribe Nine is a series that I don't regret spending time with, if only because of my insatiable desire to devour everything Kazutaka Kodaka lays his hands on. I just kind of can't help myself: every since I played Danganronpa in grad school, I've been very into everything he makes. Tribe Nine is the fast food of anime. It is is the 7-11 pizza slice of the animation world. Will it do in a pinch? Yeah, of course, but is it exactly what I wanted?    No, not at all.    There was a lot of mixed feelings as the credits rolled: I tried to reflect on what drew me to this show outside of my desire to kin my personality into every single Danganronpa character. Thinking back, it was a desire to see  a sports anime that was fun, and to a degree Tribe Nine was, at least initially. That said, I know there was an audience for this series, and I really hope that if you're that audience, you enjoyed it. Truth be told, that's always my wish for shows that I'm reviewing, whether or not I like them in the end: I hope that they brought enjoyment to as many people as possible. I'm a bit on both sides of the fence with my enjoyment, but honestly I can safely conclude this review saying that this anime is perfectly okay, and that's okay in and of itself. Every season needs its C-minus grade anime, and Tribe Nine?    Well, it's a grand slam in that category.    Rating:              because this was so close to four stars, but just never got there       Tribe Nine is currently streaming on Funimation.    Mercedez is a JP-EN translation and localization light novel editor & proofreader/QA, pop culture critic, and a journalist who, when not writing for ANN, writes for Anime Feminist, where they're a staff editor. They're also a frequent cohost on the Anime Feminist Podcast, Chatty AF. This season, they're reflecting on their youth with Akebi's Sailor Uniform. When they're not writing and reviewing, you can find them on their  Twitter or on their  Instagram where she's always up to something.   <prevEpisode 1-3 Episode 4 Episode 5 Episodes 6-7 Episode 8 Episode 9 Episode 10 Episode 11 Episode 12

Title: Episode 12 - Tribe Nine - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: How would you rate episode 12 of Tribe Nine ?                     Community score: 3.7            Time to get ready to play ball, which is coincidentally the title of Tribe Nine's grand slam of a finale (that is, “PLAY BALL” in all caps) to what I can only assume will be a one cour project as, spoiler alert: it has very little baseball, actually. But there's lots and lots of feelings.    Ojiro goes full mask off (as in, he literally takes off his mask) this week, taking on the Minato Tribe in a face-to-face battle that's full of twists and turns, including a good bit of betrayal. I love a last-minute heel turn (with GUNS!), even if it's crammed into twenty-four minutes of not the best paced scripting. But hey: that banger soundtrack though, am I right?    There is so much crammed into this episode: there's flashbacks and XB fights (and even more almost XB fights) and character growth and character deconstruction. It's all a lot, and it's not necessarily well-structured. It is fairly interesting, but maybe, in another series it would be well-executed and not feel like Tribe Nine was trying to tie up a bunch of loose ends. It ultimately feels messy, and when the resolution comes it's expected, which is really all I can say.    And since we're here, let's talk about resolutions.    I can easily say I'll be leaving the series with a solid sense of closure and a bit of optimism, which is nice, but unexpected. I genuinely thought I'd be leaving with some sort of “now go play the mobile game” bait, but instead we get an ending that feels about as good as you can expect from a show that's gone through some very high highs and extremely low lows like Tribe Nine has, cliffhangers included.    And goodness me, has this show gone through it over the past few weeks.    But where the show lands -and actually sticks the landing- is on the notion of fun. Part of why XB is so engaging for the late Shun Kamiya, and now, for Haru, is because it's a game. XB thrives when that's at the core: when it becomes a knock down, drag out battle, the game loses it's enjoyment. And it's actually this return to fun by Haru -who literally throws hands this episode- that actually kind of had me smiling in the end because say what you will, this show stays the course with its overall message, roiling the world of XB and Neo Tokyo by Game Over-ing some characters. (Or are they alive? Here's the thing, I genuinely don't know.)    Tribe Nine is a series that I don't regret spending time with, if only because of my insatiable desire to devour everything Kazutaka Kodaka lays his hands on. I just kind of can't help myself: every since I played Danganronpa in grad school, I've been very into everything he makes. Tribe Nine is the fast food of anime. It is is the 7-11 pizza slice of the animation world. Will it do in a pinch? Yeah, of course, but is it exactly what I wanted?    No, not at all.    There was a lot of mixed feelings as the credits rolled: I tried to reflect on what drew me to this show outside of my desire to kin my personality into every single Danganronpa character. Thinking back, it was a desire to see  a sports anime that was fun, and to a degree Tribe Nine was, at least initially. That said, I know there was an audience for this series, and I really hope that if you're that audience, you enjoyed it. Truth be told, that's always my wish for shows that I'm reviewing, whether or not I like them in the end: I hope that they brought enjoyment to as many people as possible. I'm a bit on both sides of the fence with my enjoyment, but honestly I can safely conclude this review saying that this anime is perfectly okay, and that's okay in and of itself. Every season needs its C-minus grade anime, and Tribe Nine?    Well, it's a grand slam in that category.    Rating:              because this was so close to four stars, but just never got there       Tribe Nine is currently streaming on Funimation. Manga Top 10       Best Rated (bayesian estimate)Worst Rated (bayesian estimate)Best Rated (weighted average)Most PopularMost ViewedMost UnderratedMost OverratedMost Diverging Opinions  Top 10 Best Rated (bayesian estimate) (Top 50)  # title rating nb. votes   1 Steel Ball Run (manga) 9.37 129   2 Berserk (manga) 9.24 1369   3 Monster (manga) 9.17 861   4 Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (manga) 9.09 701   5 Vinland Saga (manga) 9.07 259   6 Yokohama Kaidashi Kikou (manga) 9.03 366   7 20th Century Boys (manga) 8.98 604   8 Fullmetal Alchemist (manga) 8.97 1610   9 Akira (manga) 8.93 587   10 JoJolion (manga) 8.92 32  This rating only includes titles that have at least 4 votes. The bayesian estimate is a statistical technique used to reduce the noise due to low sample counts. In effect, the less a title has votes, the more it is pulled towards the mean (7.732). In other words, these are the titles that many people agree are great.  (formula)  bayesian rating = (v ÷ (v+m)) × R + (m ÷ (v+m)) × C  where:   R = average for the manga   v = number of votes for the manga   m = minimum votes required to be listed (currently 4)   C = the mean vote across the whole report (currently 7.732)    Top 10 Worst Rated (bayesian estimate) (Top 50)  # title rating nb. votes   3296 Duel Masters (manga) 4.03 7   3295 Saint Seiya Episode.G: Assassin (manga) 4.21 4   3294 Eiken (manga) 4.35 25   3293 Treasure Hunter (manga) 4.40 8   3292 Deus Vitae (manga) 4.45 41   3291 Ultimate Muscle: The Kinnikuman Legacy (manga) 4.56 37   3290 Samurai Shodown (manga, Yuki Miyoshi) 4.76 7   3289 Haruka: Beyond the Stream of Time (manga) 4.79 49   3288 Mai-chan's Daily Life (manga) 4.87 14   3287 Battle Royale II: Blitz Royale (manga) 5.07 25  This rating only includes titles that have at least 4 votes. In other words, these are the titles that many people agree are awful.  (formula)  bayesian rating = (v ÷ (v+m)) × R + (m ÷ (v+m)) × C  where:   R = average for the manga   v = number of votes for the manga   m = minimum votes required to be listed (currently 4)   C = the mean vote across the whole report (currently 7.732)    Top 10 Best Rated (weighted average) (Top 50)  # title rating nb. votes   81 Steel Ball Run (manga) 9.42 129   93 Berserk (manga) 9.24 1369   100 Monster (manga) 9.17 861   101 Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (manga) 9.10 701   102 Vinland Saga (manga) 9.09 259   104 JoJolion (manga) 9.07 32   108 Yokohama Kaidashi Kikou (manga) 9.04 366   267 20th Century Boys (manga) 8.99 604   268 Ultra Heaven (manga) 8.98 9   270 Fullmetal Alchemist (manga) 8.97 1610  The rating is an average of the scores given by voters, weighted to give less importance to users with unnatural voting patterns. Titles with less than 4 votes are removed from the list but are still counted in the ranking. This explains why there may be gaps in the "#" column. Titles with many votes will tend to be at the top, but this is modified a little by the ratings. In other words, the popularity is the straight average score of a title (the value in the rating column) multiplied by the number of votes. Title: Manga Top 10 - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: ×  remind me tomorrow remind me next week never remind me      Subscribe to the ANN Newsletter • Wake up every Sunday to a curated list of ANN's most interesting posts of the week.    read more           ข่าวสารและบทความของ Anime News Network ในรูปแบบภาษาไทย สามารถติดตามอ่านได้แล้วที่ DEXclub         กรุณาเข้าไปเยี่ยมชมได้ที่ news.dexclub.com เพื่อติดตามอ่านข่าวสารล่าสุดในรูปแบบภาษาไทย          Anime News Network's news and articles are available in Thai from DEXclub.         Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.               Manga Top 10       Best Rated (bayesian estimate)Worst Rated (bayesian estimate)Best Rated (weighted average)Most PopularMost ViewedMost UnderratedMost OverratedMost Diverging Opinions  Top 10 Best Rated (bayesian estimate) (Top 50)  # title rating nb. votes   1 Steel Ball Run (manga) 9.37 129   2 Berserk (manga) 9.24 1369   3 Monster (manga) 9.17 861   4 Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (manga) 9.09 701   5 Vinland Saga (manga) 9.07 259   6 Yokohama Kaidashi Kikou (manga) 9.03 366   7 20th Century Boys (manga) 8.98 604   8 Fullmetal Alchemist (manga) 8.97 1610   9 Akira (manga) 8.93 587   10 JoJolion (manga) 8.92 32  This rating only includes titles that have at least 4 votes. The bayesian estimate is a statistical technique used to reduce the noise due to low sample counts. In effect, the less a title has votes, the more it is pulled towards the mean (7.732). In other words, these are the titles that many people agree are great.  (formula)  bayesian rating = (v ÷ (v+m)) × R + (m ÷ (v+m)) × C  where:   R = average for the manga   v = number of votes for the manga   m = minimum votes required to be listed (currently 4)   C = the mean vote across the whole report (currently 7.732)    Top 10 Worst Rated (bayesian estimate) (Top 50)  # title rating nb. votes   3296 Duel Masters (manga) 4.03 7   3295 Saint Seiya Episode.G: Assassin (manga) 4.21 4   3294 Eiken (manga) 4.35 25   3293 Treasure Hunter (manga) 4.40 8   3292 Deus Vitae (manga) 4.45 41   3291 Ultimate Muscle: The Kinnikuman Legacy (manga) 4.56 37   3290 Samurai Shodown (manga, Yuki Miyoshi) 4.76 7   3289 Haruka: Beyond the Stream of Time (manga) 4.79 49   3288 Mai-chan's Daily Life (manga) 4.87 14   3287 Battle Royale II: Blitz Royale (manga) 5.07 25  This rating only includes titles that have at least 4 votes. The bayesian estimate is a statistical technique used to reduce the noise due to low sample counts. In effect, the less a title has votes, the more it is pulled towards the mean (7.732). In other words, these are the titles that many people agree are awful.  (formula)  bayesian rating = (v ÷ (v+m)) × R + (m ÷ (v+m)) × C  where:   R = average for the manga   v = number of votes for the manga   m = minimum votes required to be listed (currently 4)   C = the mean vote across the whole report (currently 7.732)    Top 10 Best Rated (weighted average) (Top 50)  # title rating nb. votes   81 Steel Ball Run (manga) 9.42 129   93 Berserk (manga) 9.24 1369   100 Monster (manga) 9.17 861   101 Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (manga) 9.10 701   102 Vinland Saga (manga) 9.09 259   104 JoJolion (manga) 9.07 32   108 Yokohama Kaidashi Kikou (manga) 9.04 366   267 20th Century Boys (manga) 8.99 604   268 Ultra Heaven (manga) 8.98 9   270 Fullmetal Alchemist (manga) 8.97 1610  The rating is an average of the scores given by voters, weighted to give less importance to users with unnatural voting patterns. Titles with less than 4 votes are removed from the list but are still counted in the ranking. This explains why there may be gaps in the "#" column.    Top 10 Most Popular (Top 50)  # title rating nb. votes   1 Death Note (manga) 8.86 2601   2 Naruto (manga) 8.10 2233   3 Bleach (manga) 8.11 1942   4 Fullmetal Alchemist (manga) 8.94 1610   5 Fruits Basket (manga) 8.72 1618   6 Berserk (manga) 9.27 1369   7 One Piece (manga) 8.61 1288   8 Love Hina (manga) 8.30 1335   9 Rurouni Kenshin (manga) 8.79 1246   10 Chobits (manga) 7.98 1248  The most popular titles are determined with a simple summation of all votes. Titles with many votes will tend to be at the top, but this is modified a little by the ratings. In other words, the popularity is the straight average score of a title (the value in the rating column) multiplied by the number of votes.    Top 10 Most Viewed (Top 50)  # title rating seen by   1 Naruto (manga) 8.06 5105   2 Death Note (manga) 8.84 4973   3 Bleach (manga) 8.02 4774   4 Fruits Basket (manga) 8.75 3739   5 Fullmetal Alchemist (manga) 8.97 3521   6 One Piece (manga) 8.48 2928   7 Chobits (manga) 7.88 2845   8 Love Hina (manga) 8.16 2641   9 Rurouni Kenshin (manga) 8.72 2578   10 Berserk (manga) 9.24 2503  The "seen by" column indicates the number of people who have added the title in MyAnime, either in "seen some", "seen all", or "will not finish" categories. The rating displayed here is the same weighted average as the Top 10 Best Rated by weighted average, but is only displayed for reference and doesn't have anything to do with the order of the titles.    Top 10 Most Underrated (Top 50)  # title rating seen by   +4317 Getter Robo Go (manga) 8.16 5   +4142 Sotsugyōsei -Fuyu- (manga) 8.23 6   +4035 Chio's School Road (manga) 8.12 6   +4020 Swing Shell (manga) 8.11 6   +4005 BL Metamorphosis (manga) 7.79 4   +3988 Hyouge Mono - Tea for Universe, Tea for Life (manga) 8.08 6   +3891 Gal Gohan (manga) 7.73 4   +3873 Hitler (manga) 8.15 7   +3844 Our Precious Conversations (manga) 7.86 5   +3812 Yugami-kun ni wa Tomodachi ga Inai (manga) 7.85 5  This is a list of the titles that deserve to be seen more. Based on the premise that titles deserve to be seen in equal proportion to how well rated they are, the value in the "#" column is the number of positions by which this title would climb in the Most Viewed list if it was seen as much as it was liked (according to bayesian rating).    Top 10 Most Overrated (Top 50)  # title rating seen by   -3099 Princess Ai (manga) 5.58 485   -3093 (The) Vision of Escaflowne (manga) 5.08 415   -3032 My-HiME (manga) 6.04 510   -3029 Tokyo Mew Mew a la Mode (manga) 5.85 410   -3013 Yu-Gi-Oh! (manga) 6.36 1069   -3011 Baby & Me (manga) 5.94 400   -3004 Miyuki-chan in Wonderland (manga) 5.97 404   -2976 Cowboy Bebop Shooting Star (manga) 6.20 522   -2950 Sand Land (manga) 6.23 472   -2945 Samurai Girl Real Bout High School (manga) 6.10 359  This is a list of the titles that didn't deserve to be seen as much as they have been. Based on the premise that titles deserve to be seen in equal proportion to how well rated they are, the value in the "#" column is the number of positions by which this title would drop in the Most Viewed list if it was seen as much as it was liked (according to bayesian rating).    Top 10 Most Diverging Opinions (Top 50)  # title rating nb. votes   1 Hanaotoko (manga) 7.88 ±4.048 23   2 GTO: 14 Days in Shonan (manga) 7.18 ±3.900 30   3 Haikara-san ga Tooru (manga) 8.26 ±3.758 7   4 Mai-chan's Daily Life (manga) 4.87 ±3.639 14   5 (The) World is Mine (manga) 8.55 ±3.631 23   6 Pheromomania Syndrome (manga) 7.14 ±3.586 7   7 Apocalypse Zero (manga) 7.30 ±3.511 11   8 Interspecies Reviewers (manga) 8.03 ±3.491 4   9 (The) Place Promised in Our Early Days (manga) 7.14 ±3.491 4   10 Ultimate Muscle: The Kinnikuman Legacy (manga) 4.56 ±3.491 37  Only includes titles with at least 4 votes. The rating column contains the baysesian rating ± the standard deviation, with the order of the titles being determined by the standard deviation. Back to top                  thadec    Joined: 02 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 16       Posted: Fri Apr 08, 2022 1:07 pm            With the exception of masterpieces like Kaiji, I normally avoid single sex shows - whether all male or all female - but I will make an exception in this case for at least 2 or 3 episodes just to see what the show content is like. If it is a VERY short form series with 3 to 5 minute episodes like  Master of Killing Time or Super Seisyun Brothers, fine. But I can't fathom 22 minutes for 13 episodes - or even 12 minutes like Tsuredure Children - where the content consists of a character just speculating. If it is school hi-jinks or if they have ninja missions with combat then why not promote that also?    I know, I could answer these questions by just checking out the source material, but that costs money (reserved for "actually have an interest in reading" not "what on earth is going on in the first place?"). Back to top                  thadec    Joined: 02 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 16       Posted: Fri Apr 08, 2022 9:02 pm              MFrontier wrote:    I feel like this show is trying to hit a record for the amount of female characters...            Well, I guess packing as many middle school girls that aren't wearing a whole lot - because they're ninjas, and not something girly like idols or sketchy like models! - as possible and contains a bit of "wink wink" humor but still comes nowhere near ecchi is an excellent way to maximize readership among middle school boys. Forum - View topicNEWS: In the Heart of Kunoichi Tsubaki Anime Reveals 3 More Cast Members             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        JustMonika    Joined: 17 Jan 2022 		    Posts: 90       Posted: Fri Apr 08, 2022 5:13 am            Getting really excited for this one!      Back to top                  thadec    Joined: 02 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 16       Posted: Fri Apr 08, 2022 1:07 pm            With the exception of masterpieces like Kaiji, I normally avoid single sex shows - whether all male or all female - but I will make an exception in this case for at least 2 or 3 episodes just to see what the show content is like. If it is a VERY short form series with 3 to 5 minute episodes like  Master of Killing Time or Super Seisyun Brothers, fine. But I can't fathom 22 minutes for 13 episodes - or even 12 minutes like Tsuredure Children - where the content consists of a character just speculating. If it is school hi-jinks or if they have ninja missions with combat then why not promote that also?    I know, I could answer these questions by just checking out the source material, but that costs money (reserved for "actually have an interest in reading" not "what on earth is going on in the first place?").      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3824       Posted: Fri Apr 08, 2022 4:31 pm            I feel like this show is trying to hit a record for the amount of female characters...      Back to top                  thadec    Joined: 02 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 16       Posted: Fri Apr 08, 2022 9:02 pm              MFrontier wrote:    I feel like this show is trying to hit a record for the amount of female characters...            Well, I guess packing as many middle school girls that aren't wearing a whole lot - because they're ninjas, and not something girly like idols or sketchy like models! - as possible and contains a bit of "wink wink" humor but still comes nowhere near ecchi is an excellent way to maximize readership among middle school boys. "Hey kid want to look at a ton of pictures of an amazing variety of pretty girls that are about your age and laugh at a lot of silly 'just a little bit naughty' jokes without getting scolded by your parents or embarrassed at school? Well here you go!"    So yeah I can see why this would have been a real hit as a manga. I just don't see how to carry that over into a successful TV show.      Back to top                  Swissman    Joined: 11 May 2006 		    Posts: 672 		    Location: Switzerland 		        Posted: Sat Apr 09, 2022 4:46 am              thadec wrote:    So yeah I can see why this would have been a real hit as a manga. I just don't see how to carry that over into a successful TV show.           it's based on a manga by Souichiro Yamamoto, an artist who has a strong fanbase thanks to Teasing Master Takagi, which is also a hit as an anime. You'd be a fool not to adapt Yamamoto's other works into animation, he's a golden goose right now.  I'vre read the original manga and I like it. It's a cute, inoffensive SoL comedy with great chemistry between the many girls. It's perfect for a feel good romcom anime. Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.                Yoshiki Superstar Project X: Join us, You're the Next Super Star   Apr  9th 2022         Join us! You're the next super star! Go global together! “Nothing is Impossible!”  With the strongest members from Japan to the world, a boy band audition to discover the next superstar - produced by YOSHIKI.  “YOSHIKI SUPERSTAR PROJECT X” We've got massive response, with some days receiving about 1,000 applications! With number of demands for extension of the application period, we've decided to accept additional applicants! Group (multiple-member) application is also accepted!  The detail of the audition is being revealed gradually! Two groups may debut - a dance & vocal group, and a band. Worldclass specialists from different genre will be gathered as a training team!  “YOSHIKI SUPERSTAR PROJECT X” - YOSHIKI as a producer, the audition to find and develop the world's next iconic a boy band will be accepting additional applicants starting noon on Monday, April 11. This time in response to many inquiries, applicant as a band or a group is also accepted.  During the online meeting on March 31 between YOSHIKI in LA and NTV audition staff broadcasted live on “YOSHIKI CHANNEL,” they discussed about the day they received about 1,000 applications in a single day, and also about the messages they were receiving such as “application period is too short,” “I'm not sure what kind of video to take,” and so on. In response, YOSHIKI brought up an idea of additional call for application, and the details were released today.  Also during the program, YOSHIKI expressed his vision about the group saying, “I have a feeling two different groups may debut; a dance & vocal group and a band.” He also said, “After meeting applicants in person, my ideas may change - and in that sense, this audition is a collaboration of applicants and us.” He also quoted about his detailed plans about their debut, “At this point, we're looking at the timing sometime between the end of this year and spring, and I also want to prepare the right stage for that day.”  About the training team for the group, YOSHIKI says “I'm reaching out to worldwide specialists in various genre: for instance, people like fashion experts and voice trainers.” YOSHIKI has lived in Hollywood for some time and has a wide network of contacts worldwide, and therefore a strongest team possible is planned to be put together.  YOSHIKI seems to be gradually watching the performances of the applicants. He comments,“Maybe I can set aside some time to watch all the performances with a hachimaki wrapped around my head (laugh)!” He also shared his surprising episode of him meeting an applicant who was a staff of the restaurant he went in LA.  For upcoming auditions, he's now trying to set his schedule so that he can meet the applicants in person. As of the selection criteria, according to YOSHIKI, “ I will be cooperating with specialists of each genre, but I am an artist myself and also a producer, and I do wide range of music from rock to classic. So, for instance, I may notice something other great producers may not notice. From the perspective as a rock musician, I may find things in a dance & vocal group which professional dancers may not find. I have confidence in my keen eye for finding new talent.”  To this day, YOSHIKI has challenged “the existing concept of what is normal” and created a new era. With his keen eye to find true talent, this time as a producer, we can't wait to see how he will deal with the applicants, with what kind of criteria he uses for selection, and finally, what kind of a boy band he will produce – this reality show sets itself apart from the many other audition programs looking for new talents.  With strongest members from Japan to the world – “YOSHIKI SUPERSTAR PROJECT X” – YOSHIKI as a producer, this competition series will be aired on “Sukkiri” and “Gyoretsu no dekiru sodanjo” (NTV) and also streamed on Hulu. Please check our official website for details on additional applications, beginning noon on Monday, April 11.  ≪YOSHIKI's comment≫ Thank you for all of you who already applied. We are finding lots of wonderful performances. As I have experienced, going through audition is a tough procedure, forcing you to compete. You need to be strong mentally, and there will be number of challenges you'll face. It's so easy to give up, but including myself, I chose the tough way and moving forward on this path. I look forward to meeting such people through this audition.  As in the title “Superstar,” our staff and I are all working together so we can bring out a superstar to the world, so even if you aren't sure about yourself, please don't hesitate! I am so excited to meet all of you.  ≪Audition Outline≫  Audition name: “YOSHIKI SUPERSTAR PROJECT X” First recruitment for a boy band: March 1 ~ March 31, 2022 (application now closed) Additional recruitment for a boy band: Monday, April 11 noon ~ Friday, May 20 23:59 Official website: https://yoshikisuperstar.com/en/ Official Twitter: @ YOSHIKI_s_star Official Instagram: @yoshikisuperstar Official TikTok: @yoshikisuperstar     discuss this in the forum |        bookmark/share with:               Press Release homepage / archives           RightStuf - Anime, Manga and More          ⬈ ⬋ - +                            news          7 comments       Makoto Shinkai Unveils New Anime Film Suzume no Tojimari's Heroine, November 11 Opening   Apr  9, 08:20 7 comments                 anime    Still also posted before teaser's debut on Sunday ― Makoto Shinkai (your name., Weathering With You) revealed the title heroine's visual, a still, and the November 11 opening for his first new film in three years, Suzume no Tojimari (literally, Suzume's Door-Locking), on Saturday. Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.                Yoshiki Superstar Project X: Join us, You're the Next Super Star   Apr  9th 2022         Join us! You're the next super star! Go global together! “Nothing is Impossible!”  With the strongest members from Japan to the world, a boy band audition to discover the next superstar - produced by YOSHIKI.  “YOSHIKI SUPERSTAR PROJECT X” We've got massive response, with some days receiving about 1,000 applications! With number of demands for extension of the application period, we've decided to accept additional applicants! Group (multiple-member) application is also accepted!  The detail of the audition is being revealed gradually! Two groups may debut - a dance & vocal group, and a band. Worldclass specialists from different genre will be gathered as a training team!  “YOSHIKI SUPERSTAR PROJECT X” - YOSHIKI as a producer, the audition to find and develop the world's next iconic a boy band will be accepting additional applicants starting noon on Monday, April 11. This time in response to many inquiries, applicant as a band or a group is also accepted.  During the online meeting on March 31 between YOSHIKI in LA and NTV audition staff broadcasted live on “YOSHIKI CHANNEL,” they discussed about the day they received about 1,000 applications in a single day, and also about the messages they were receiving such as “application period is too short,” “I'm not sure what kind of video to take,” and so on. In response, YOSHIKI brought up an idea of additional call for application, and the details were released today.  Also during the program, YOSHIKI expressed his vision about the group saying, “I have a feeling two different groups may debut; a dance & vocal group and a band.” He also said, “After meeting applicants in person, my ideas may change - and in that sense, this audition is a collaboration of applicants and us.” He also quoted about his detailed plans about their debut, “At this point, we're looking at the timing sometime between the end of this year and spring, and I also want to prepare the right stage for that day.”  About the training team for the group, YOSHIKI says “I'm reaching out to worldwide specialists in various genre: for instance, people like fashion experts and voice trainers.” YOSHIKI has lived in Hollywood for some time and has a wide network of contacts worldwide, and therefore a strongest team possible is planned to be put together.  YOSHIKI seems to be gradually watching the performances of the applicants. He comments,“Maybe I can set aside some time to watch all the performances with a hachimaki wrapped around my head (laugh)!” He also shared his surprising episode of him meeting an applicant who was a staff of the restaurant he went in LA.  For upcoming auditions, he's now trying to set his schedule so that he can meet the applicants in person. As of the selection criteria, according to YOSHIKI, “ I will be cooperating with specialists of each genre, but I am an artist myself and also a producer, and I do wide range of music from rock to classic. So, for instance, I may notice something other great producers may not notice. From the perspective as a rock musician, I may find things in a dance & vocal group which professional dancers may not find. I have confidence in my keen eye for finding new talent.”  To this day, YOSHIKI has challenged “the existing concept of what is normal” and created a new era. With his keen eye to find true talent, this time as a producer, we can't wait to see how he will deal with the applicants, with what kind of criteria he uses for selection, and finally, what kind of a boy band he will produce – this reality show sets itself apart from the many other audition programs looking for new talents.  With strongest members from Japan to the world – “YOSHIKI SUPERSTAR PROJECT X” – YOSHIKI as a producer, this competition series will be aired on “Sukkiri” and “Gyoretsu no dekiru sodanjo” (NTV) and also streamed on Hulu. Please check our official website for details on additional applications, beginning noon on Monday, April 11.  ≪YOSHIKI's comment≫ Thank you for all of you who already applied. We are finding lots of wonderful performances. As I have experienced, going through audition is a tough procedure, forcing you to compete. You need to be strong mentally, and there will be number of challenges you'll face. It's so easy to give up, but including myself, I chose the tough way and moving forward on this path. I look forward to meeting such people through this audition.  As in the title “Superstar,” our staff and I are all working together so we can bring out a superstar to the world, so even if you aren't sure about yourself, please don't hesitate! I am so excited to meet all of you.  ≪Audition Outline≫  Audition name: “YOSHIKI SUPERSTAR PROJECT X” First recruitment for a boy band: March 1 ~ March 31, 2022 (application now closed) Additional recruitment for a boy band: Monday, April 11 noon ~ Friday, May 20 23:59 Official website: https://yoshikisuperstar.com/en/ Official Twitter: @ YOSHIKI_s_star Official Instagram: @yoshikisuperstar Official TikTok: @yoshikisuperstar     discuss this in the forum |        bookmark/share with:               Press Release homepage / archives           RightStuf - Anime, Manga and More          ⬈ ⬋ - +                            news          7 comments       Makoto Shinkai Unveils New Anime Film Suzume no Tojimari's Heroine, November 11 Opening   Apr  9, 08:20 7 comments                 anime    Still also posted before teaser's debut on Sunday ― Makoto Shinkai (your name., Weathering With You) revealed the title heroine's visual, a still, and the November 11 opening for his first new film in three years, Suzume no Tojimari (literally, Suzume's Door-Locking), on Saturday. News 'I'm Quitting Heroing' TV Anime's Blu-ray/DVD Adds New 2-Part Anime   posted on 2022-04-06 13:12 UTC-8 by Rafael Antonio Pineda         12-episode TV anime offered in 2 boxes on June 24, August 24    The official website for the television anime of Quantum and Hana Amano's I'm Quitting Heroing: Next Gig Is at the Demon Queen's Castle (Yūsha, Yamemasu: Tsugi no Shokuba wa Maōjō) fantasy light novel series announced on Wednesday that the anime will ship in two Blu-ray Disc (or DVD) boxes on June 24 and August 24. The boxes will contain 12 television episodes and  a new two-part anime titled "Kenshū Ryokō wa Mokuteki o Ushinau na" (Don't Lose Sight of Why We Took This Research Trip).    The anime premiered on Tuesday. Sentai Filmworks acquired exclusive rights to the anime, and is streaming it on HIDIVE and release it on home video.    The cast includes:     Kensho Ono as Leo Demonheart   Kaede Hondo as Echidna   Shizuka Itou as Steiner   Hitomi Ohwada as Lily   Yumi Uchiyama as Mernes   Tetsu Inada as Edvard   Minori Suzuki as Dianette   Misato Matsuoka as Jerietta    The story centers on Leo, a hero who once saved the world from a demon army's invasion. However, he was feared and ostracized by people afterward, and ended up with no job. Feeling that his skills would be better appreciated elsewhere, he joins the demon lord's army that he once fought. Now in a new work environment, Leo strives to use his skills and revive the demon army that is on the brink of collapse.    Yuu Nobuta (High School Fleet, Maesetsu! Opening Act, The Faraway Paladin) is credited as chief director, while Hisashi Ishii (Rainy Cocoa side G, Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) is directing the series at EMT Squared. Shigeru Murakoshi (Zombie Land Saga, to the abandoned Sacred Beasts, The Gymnastics Samurai) is in charge of the series scripts. Yuki Nakano (A Destructive God Sits Next to Me, Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) is designing the characters.    Minori Suzuki performs the opening theme song "Broken Identity." Nao Tōyama performs the ending theme song "Growing."    Quantum published the story on the Kakuyomu story website in 2017. Kadokawa is publishing the story in print with illustrations by Amano, and it released the third volume in October 2018.    Nori Kazato launched a manga adaptation of the novels on Kadokawa's Young Ace Up web manga site in May 2018. Kadokawa published the manga's fifth volume in May 2021. The cast includes:     Kensho Ono as Leo Demonheart   Kaede Hondo as Echidna   Shizuka Itou as Steiner   Hitomi Ohwada as Lily   Yumi Uchiyama as Mernes   Tetsu Inada as Edvard   Minori Suzuki as Dianette   Misato Matsuoka as Jerietta    The story centers on Leo, a hero who once saved the world from a demon army's invasion. However, he was feared and ostracized by people afterward, and ended up with no job. Feeling that his skills would be better appreciated elsewhere, he joins the demon lord's army that he once fought. Now in a new work environment, Leo strives to use his skills and revive the demon army that is on the brink of collapse.    Yuu Nobuta (High School Fleet, Maesetsu! Opening Act, The Faraway Paladin) is credited as chief director, while Hisashi Ishii (Rainy Cocoa side G, Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) is directing the series at EMT Squared. Shigeru Murakoshi (Zombie Land Saga, to the abandoned Sacred Beasts, The Gymnastics Samurai) is in charge of the series scripts. Yuki Nakano (A Destructive God Sits Next to Me, Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) is designing the characters.    Minori Suzuki performs the opening theme song "Broken Identity." Nao Tōyama performs the ending theme song "Growing."    Quantum published the story on the Kakuyomu story website in 2017. Kadokawa is publishing the story in print with illustrations by Amano, and it released the third volume in October 2018.    Nori Kazato launched a manga adaptation of the novels on Kadokawa's Young Ace Up web manga site in May 2018. Kadokawa published the manga's fifth volume in May 2021. News 'I'm Quitting Heroing' TV Anime's Blu-ray/DVD Adds New 2-Part Anime   posted on 2022-04-06 13:12 UTC-8 by Rafael Antonio Pineda         12-episode TV anime offered in 2 boxes on June 24, August 24    The official website for the television anime of Quantum and Hana Amano's I'm Quitting Heroing: Next Gig Is at the Demon Queen's Castle (Yūsha, Yamemasu: Tsugi no Shokuba wa Maōjō) fantasy light novel series announced on Wednesday that the anime will ship in two Blu-ray Disc (or DVD) boxes on June 24 and August 24. The boxes will contain 12 television episodes and  a new two-part anime titled "Kenshū Ryokō wa Mokuteki o Ushinau na" (Don't Lose Sight of Why We Took This Research Trip).    The anime premiered on Tuesday. Sentai Filmworks acquired exclusive rights to the anime, and is streaming it on HIDIVE and release it on home video.    The cast includes:     Kensho Ono as Leo Demonheart   Kaede Hondo as Echidna   Shizuka Itou as Steiner   Hitomi Ohwada as Lily   Yumi Uchiyama as Mernes   Tetsu Inada as Edvard   Minori Suzuki as Dianette   Misato Matsuoka as Jerietta    The story centers on Leo, a hero who once saved the world from a demon army's invasion. However, he was feared and ostracized by people afterward, and ended up with no job. Feeling that his skills would be better appreciated elsewhere, he joins the demon lord's army that he once fought. Now in a new work environment, Leo strives to use his skills and revive the demon army that is on the brink of collapse.    Yuu Nobuta (High School Fleet, Maesetsu! Opening Act, The Faraway Paladin) is credited as chief director, while Hisashi Ishii (Rainy Cocoa side G, Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) is directing the series at EMT Squared. Shigeru Murakoshi (Zombie Land Saga, to the abandoned Sacred Beasts, The Gymnastics Samurai) is in charge of the series scripts. Yuki Nakano (A Destructive God Sits Next to Me, Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) is designing the characters.    Minori Suzuki performs the opening theme song "Broken Identity." Nao Tōyama performs the ending theme song "Growing."    Quantum published the story on the Kakuyomu story website in 2017. Kadokawa is publishing the story in print with illustrations by Amano, and it released the third volume in October 2018.    Nori Kazato launched a manga adaptation of the novels on Kadokawa's Young Ace Up web manga site in May 2018. Kadokawa published the manga's fifth volume in May 2021. Title: 'I'm Quitting Heroing' TV Anime's Blu-ray/DVD Adds New 2-Part Anime - News - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: ×  remind me tomorrow remind me next week never remind me      Subscribe to the ANN Newsletter • Wake up every Sunday to a curated list of ANN's most interesting posts of the week.    read more           ข่าวสารและบทความของ Anime News Network ในรูปแบบภาษาไทย สามารถติดตามอ่านได้แล้วที่ DEXclub         กรุณาเข้าไปเยี่ยมชมได้ที่ news.dexclub.com เพื่อติดตามอ่านข่าวสารล่าสุดในรูปแบบภาษาไทย          Anime News Network's news and articles are available in Thai from DEXclub.         Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.             News 'I'm Quitting Heroing' TV Anime's Blu-ray/DVD Adds New 2-Part Anime   posted on 2022-04-06 13:12 UTC-8 by Rafael Antonio Pineda         12-episode TV anime offered in 2 boxes on June 24, August 24    The official website for the television anime of Quantum and Hana Amano's I'm Quitting Heroing: Next Gig Is at the Demon Queen's Castle (Yūsha, Yamemasu: Tsugi no Shokuba wa Maōjō) fantasy light novel series announced on Wednesday that the anime will ship in two Blu-ray Disc (or DVD) boxes on June 24 and August 24. The boxes will contain 12 television episodes and  a new two-part anime titled "Kenshū Ryokō wa Mokuteki o Ushinau na" (Don't Lose Sight of Why We Took This Research Trip).    The anime premiered on Tuesday. Sentai Filmworks acquired exclusive rights to the anime, and is streaming it on HIDIVE and release it on home video.    The cast includes:     Kensho Ono as Leo Demonheart   Kaede Hondo as Echidna   Shizuka Itou as Steiner   Hitomi Ohwada as Lily   Yumi Uchiyama as Mernes   Tetsu Inada as Edvard   Minori Suzuki as Dianette   Misato Matsuoka as Jerietta    The story centers on Leo, a hero who once saved the world from a demon army's invasion. However, he was feared and ostracized by people afterward, and ended up with no job. Feeling that his skills would be better appreciated elsewhere, he joins the demon lord's army that he once fought. Now in a new work environment, Leo strives to use his skills and revive the demon army that is on the brink of collapse.    Yuu Nobuta (High School Fleet, Maesetsu! Opening Act, The Faraway Paladin) is credited as chief director, while Hisashi Ishii (Rainy Cocoa side G, Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) is directing the series at EMT Squared. Shigeru Murakoshi (Zombie Land Saga, to the abandoned Sacred Beasts, The Gymnastics Samurai) is in charge of the series scripts. Yuki Nakano (A Destructive God Sits Next to Me, Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) is designing the characters.    Minori Suzuki performs the opening theme song "Broken Identity." Nao Tōyama performs the ending theme song "Growing."    Quantum published the story on the Kakuyomu story website in 2017. Kadokawa is publishing the story in print with illustrations by Amano, and it released the third volume in October 2018.    Nori Kazato launched a manga adaptation of the novels on Kadokawa's Young Ace Up web manga site in May 2018. Kadokawa published the manga's fifth volume in May 2021.    Source: I'm Quitting Heroing anime's website via Ota-Suke        discuss this in the forum (2 posts) |        bookmark/share with:                News homepage / archives           RightStuf - Anime, Manga and More
